DeregistrationReasonOtherText: EPA has administratively marked this facility as 'Closed'.

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Services to Buildings and Dwellings

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Tri-County Pool Service, Inc. provides chlorination for recreational swimming pools in the Salida, California area.  Tri-County Pool Service has ensured a safe operation dating back to 1960.

Tri-County Pool Service's manager/owner is personally committed to offer superior service and to maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The owner administers the company's safety and environmental policies. He is also responsible for various inspections to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include, hazard communications, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Action Plan, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED

Startup of the chlorine system occurred in 1960.  The process is located at 5012A Salida Blvd., Salida, California 95368.  The chlorine system for Tri-County Pool Service, Inc. consists of chlorine one-ton containers which are the storage vessels.  Chlorine gas is drawn from the ton container to 20 pound cylinders.  The following is a list of the chlorine equipment.

Chlorine Tanks (one ton containers)
(2 - Operational and Maximum Amount)

Filling Manifold

Scrubber System

The maximum quantity of chlorine that can be stored on site for the Tri-County Pool Service, Inc. is 4,000 pounds.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Tri-County Pool Service, Inc. has a Process Safety Management program in place to manage the handling of chlorine.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute.  In addition to the Management Programs, there is a scrubber system that is used in conj

unction while transferring chlorine.  A manual alarm is located near the chlorine fill station which can be activated to warn employees in the case of a chlorine release.  The area is secured with crash posts and the ton containers are secured to stands in case of an earthquake.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Based upon the Hazard Assessment Addendum (April 2004) the five year accident history investigation (June 1999 - June 2004) revealed that there have been no reportable releases of chlorine at the facility.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

If a release of chlorine were to occur, Tri-County Pool Service, Inc.'s action plan is to call 911 in order to reach the Fire Department's HAZMAT team.  Tri-County Pool Service, Inc. has a B-kit available at the facility for the HAZMAT team's use in order to mitigate a chlorine release.  Employees will evacuate the facility to a point that is upwind of the hazard.  Evacuation drills are performed annually.  The emergency action plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, and to ensure that the plan is kept current.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Tri-County Pool Service has conducted a PSM/RMP Compliance Audit (May 2004) and revalidated the Process Hazard Analysis (May 2004).  All recommendations resulting from the audit will be completed by December 2004.  The Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation revealed that no necessary modifications are needed to ensure a safe operation. 

The Process Safety Management team will continue to provide a safe environment by ensuring employee involvement in safety development and training.
